entry.title: Lofoten Day 4
entry.summary: Waking up at 06:30 am I decide to go on…
entry.content:
Waking up at 06:30 am I decide to go on a quick morning hike before the weather starts closing in. Frode (who is becoming kind of indispensable) had recommended a short walk to a viewpoint close to our cabin off the main road. I can sense Odin, the local one-tonner elk, lurking in the bushes but sadly he doesn't make an appearance. Or perhaps just as well in case he hasn't had breakfast yet. Do elks even eat meat? Most likely not.

Medha is opting for a relaxed day at the cottage today, so I decide to drive to Nusfjord and do a coastal hike to Nestland. As coastal paths go, it's a constant up and down. Plus some ladders and chains thrown in. I am quite lucky to not get rained on much, some little drizzly showers are not to be avoided, though.Â 

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

entry.title: Lofoten Day 3
entry.summary: There are clouds in the sky! Out-ra-geous!!! To add more…
entry.content:
There are clouds in the sky! Out-ra-geous!!! To add more outrageous behaviour to our day, we go on the tourist trail. Which means we drive back towards Reine to do the two most popular Lofoten hikes in one day: Kvalvika Beach and Reinebringen. Thanks to Frode (again), however, it doesn't turn out to be as bad as we fear as he had suggested to hike up Reinebringen in the late afternoon / early evening for the best lights. Which means we start our first hike to Kvalvika when a lot of people are already finished with their program. And on the popular Reinebringen summit I count 8 (!) people when I arrive at the top. Well, there are more coming, but it doesn't feel at all too packed out. And the views are as stunning as promised. Been there (now), done that. What next? Sadly, it looks like it'll be rain. But we'll see. Another Frode promise: it never rains the whole day. It always clears up. It's just the question when. You will read it in tomorrow's post.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

entry.title: Lofoten Day 2
entry.summary: The day starts with a jump into the lake. Well,…
entry.content:
The day starts with a jump into the lake. Well, more of a timid waddle actually. But I do manage to last for about a minute before the cold becomes too much to bear. We are taking it very slow this morning, enjoy our deck with the lake views and don't get going until about 1 pm. Today we are exploring the Sandoya peninsula where - as we are to learn from Frode - the first settlement of the Lofoten was founded. Another interesting fact we come to learn about is that in this part of the Vestvagoya community you can find the oldest (3 billion years) rocks. After a short drive by car we start our walk around the little peninsula and are rewarded with more stunning views of distant mountains rising up behind the water. And more solitude. Another wet moment, this time in the Atlantic, is a Must. The deserted beach we find ourselves on just invites to try the waters. Bloody cold as well.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

entry.title: Lofoten Day 1
entry.summary: Where do I begin to describe this unbelievable scenery here…
entry.content:
Where do I begin to describe this unbelievable scenery here on Lofoten? It starts in the morning with a nice breakfast on our terrace overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. We get moving at 09.30 am having decided to just drive a couple of minutes to the next village to start our hike to Munkebu. Or that's what we think until I realize I have completely cocked up the navigation and we are on a steep trail with ropes and iron chains that isn't even described in any walking guide. Which is our luck as we almost hike up to the top of what we now realize is Tindslinden (or Tintin as we call it for short) in almost complete solitude. The reward of this sweaty endeavour are the most stunning views from the top. Medha has managed to advance from a beginners mountain goat with a short intermediate mountain goat phase to advanced mountain goat within one day on Lofoten. Running down the mountain like a spring chicken, it's at times hard for me to keep up (and I never thought I'd say something like that in my life). I told her she'd regret it but she didn't want to listen. The groaning starts in the evening. But I'm having none of it. You get what you deserve.

After the hike it's driving for about 1 1/2 hours to the Eagle View Cabin where we'll be staying for the next 5 nights. Another amazing location right by a lake. Which means mosquitos. Not so nice. We even meet Frode, the manager, as we have internet problems and he comes to sort a tripped fuse out. Which obviously we could have done ourselves if we'd had the key to the room where the box is hidden. It turns out to be a blessing, though, that we get to talk to him as he is giving some very good information on the area and what to do at what time (which includes hiking, moose stalking, sunset time on the beach and Northern Light watching at its best). We badly fail at the moose stalking, don't even find the beach which is supposedly only 12 minutes away; did see a sunset, though, so that's half the achievement, at least. And the Northern Lights? Well, they were there ever so faintly, but not really worth staying awake until about 1.30 am and driving around gravel paths in the darkness.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

entry.title: Another evening hike(let)
entry.summary: It's a bit difficult to find our little Fisherman's cabin…
entry.content:
It's a bit difficult to find our little Fisherman's cabin right by the sea. When we eventually do, we just quickly drop our stuff inside and head out for our first exploratory hike(let). We are not disappointed. Just when you thought it couldn't possibly get any better, it does. Do we dare hope we might even be in for a Northern Light night? Probably not as we are too tired to attempt staying awake.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

entry.title: Crossing over to Lofoten
entry.summary: We are lucky to be allowed onto the 4 pm…
entry.content:
We are lucky to be allowed onto the 4 pm ferry even though our booking is for the last one which leaves Bodo at 6.45 pm. Which means we reach our destination 2 hours ahead of schedule. The weather couldn't be better, sunny and warm. The views back to the main land as well as to the Lofoten further into the crossing are breathtaking. The crossing itself is getting a bit choppy the further out into the Atlantic we are getting.

entry.title: Day 4 on the road
entry.summary: Today I am crossing the Arctic Circle. It's another brilliant…
entry.content:
Today I am crossing the Arctic Circle. It's another brilliant driving day. Only 250 km to Bodo Airport, but what stunning scenery! Medha's flight is on time, and by 3 pm my lonely days are officially over.Â 

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

entry.title: An evening hike(let)
entry.summary: After a 10 hour drive it's time to stretch those…
entry.content:
After a 10 hour drive it's time to stretch those legs. The owner of the little hut I am staying in overnight (overlooking one of Norway's zillions of fjords) points me to a path right by the cabin, and up I hike. It's not as convenient as hiking in the German Alps as there is quite a bit of undergrowth to juggle with, but in about half an hour I come to a little clearing with some nice views. As it is already getting late, I sensibly decide to turn around making this a short but nice little change to my driving routine.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

entry.title: Day 3 on the road
entry.summary: It's the longest driving day yet. Almost 10 hours for…
entry.content:
It's the longest driving day yet. Almost 10 hours for about 650 km including one ferry crossing. The scenery is suddenly very different the further up North I am getting. It reminds me of Finland or Sweden with loads of trees and lakes. This will be my last day of solitude as Medha will be arriving tomorrow in Bodo by plane. Then our Lofoten adventure can begin.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use â â keys

Â

entry.title: Atlantic Ocean Road
entry.summary: I thought the Atlantic Ocean Road deserves its own post.
entry.content:
I thought the Atlantic Ocean Road deserves its own post. Not because I have to drive it twice thanks to Mr. TomTom, once from East to West, then back from West to East to get back to my accomodation in Sveggvika. But because it really is a stunning piece of road, indeed. Being only a mere 8 km long and made up of 8 bridges, it claims to be one of the most scenic drives in the world, hugging the Atlantic coast, at some places right on the edge. The construction of the road started in August 1983 and it took six years to finish it. So it's not surprising that it is usually packed out with tourists. I am quite lucky today, not only because the weather is a bit moody but also because the main tourist season is coming to an end. One thing is certain: under no circumstances would I ever want to come here in July or early August when everyone is flogging this stretch of road.Â
